text: it's been announced that more people in
the uk are to become eligible for an
automatic pardon for historical
convictions for same sex and they're
going to have them wiped from their
records the uk government's widening the
current scheme in an amendment to
legislation currently going through
parliament
uh of correspondent matt graveling is

pardons are are being widened
essentially well victoria the government

for having a same-sex relationship now
historically there were a number of laws
against same-sex relationships um which
saw people fired from their jobs
and even sent to prison now obviously
this ruined people's lives not only at
the time but in the years that followed
with people having him on their record
so even
even today if they went for a job they
would have to disclose
this conviction now i'll tell you about

to play a clip from dr carl austin beer
now he's the former lord mayor of

if he'd had homosexual preferences
i realized that i either become true to
myself
um or i just you know i'd lie about it
and i was i just broke burst into tears
and i lost my job straight away i was

and i could have gone to prison

you lost everything within 10 minutes i

kicked out and
and as i say that you know

victoria 25 years on you can still hear
the upset there in carl's voice so
what's changing well since 2012 people
in england and wells have been able to
apply to have historical same-sex sexual
cautions and convictions disregarded
however campaigners said that the list
was too narrow it didn't include enough
offences and that's what the government
are looking to change now the home
secretary said they will extend the
government's disregards and pardon
scheme to ensure that anyone convicted
or cautioned under laws that have since
been abolished can apply to have them
wiped from their criminal records and
this will also um include people who
have since passed away now how can they
i mean that's one of the arguments they
shouldn't have to apply it should just
be done sure well the government say it
will be for people who have passed away
it'll be automatic because in 2017 they
brought in um turing's law named after
the wartime code broker alan turing who
was convicted of gross indecency for
homosexual acts he was pardoned 60 years
after his death so in 2017 they brought
in that automatic clearing of records
for people who had passed on and they
say it's going to be a further
adaptation of that i just want to bring
you briefly victoria um a response from
stonewall charity for lgbt rights and
they said they welcomed this news and
they told me that countless gay and
bisexual men have had their lives and
careers turned upside down from the
burden of carrying these unjust
convictions on their record now while
the grave harm this has already caused
cannot be undone the home secretary's
decisive action is a huge step toward
righting the wrongs of the past and i'm
sure thousands of people will be able to
move forward with their lives with a
clean slate thank you very much thank
you
